title: Hydraulic Scale

icon_data.statement: This question, for starting ME2 students, is a deliberately easy refresher question to get you back into the swing of things.

master_statement: A piston of diameter \(\mathrm{D = 0.1\,m}\) is fitted inside a U-shaped tube filled with liquid mercury (with \(\mathrm{density = 13,540\,kgm^{-3}}\)), as shown by the sketch below. The mercury rises by \(\mathrm{h = 1\,mm}\) under the weight of the piston.

parts.statement: What is the mass \(m\) of the piston?

worked_solutions.text: We may combine these equations, cancelling out \(p\).

worked_solutions.equation: \(\begin{eqnarray} \frac{mg}{A_{piston}} + p_{atm} = &p& = \rho g h + p_{atm}\\ \frac{m}{\pi (\frac{ \mathrm{0.1} }{2})^2} &=& \rho h\\ m &=& \rho \pi h \left(\frac{\mathrm{0.1}}{2}\right)^2\\ m &=& \pi(\mathrm{13,540})(\mathrm{0.001})(\mathrm{0.05})^2\\ m &=& \mathrm{0.1063 kg} \end{eqnarray}\)

parts.statement: What would be the effect of increasing the diameter of the gauge-tube from 2 mm to 4 mm?

worked_solutions.text: As the expression for pressure in the gauge-tube is not dependent on its cross-sectional area, the size of the tube makes causes no change to \(h\).
We may combine these equations, cancelling out \(p\).

worked_solutions.equation: \(\begin{eqnarray} \frac{mg}{A_{piston}} + p_{atm} = &p& = \rho g h + p_{atm}\\ \frac{m}{\pi (\frac{ \mathrm{0.1} }{2})^2} &=& \rho h\\ m &=& \rho \pi h \left(\frac{\mathrm{0.1}}{2}\right)^2\\ m &=& \pi(\mathrm{13,540})(\mathrm{0.001})(\mathrm{0.05})^2\\ m &=& \mathrm{0.1063 kg} \end{eqnarray}\)
